StringWithMarkup.String: MeSH (Medical Subject Headings) is the NLM controlled vocabulary thesaurus used for indexing articles for PubMed.
The ChEBI Ontology is a structured classification of the entities contained within ChEBI.
ChEBI subsumes and replaces the Chemical Ontology first
developed by Michael Ashburner & Pankaj Jaiswal.

StringWithMarkup.String: The LIPID MAPS comprehensive classification system for lipids is comprised of eight lipid categories: Fatty acyls (FA), Glycerolipids (GL), Glycerophospholipids (GP), Sphingolipids (SP), Sterol lipids (ST), Prenol lipids (PR), Saccharolipids (SL) and Polyketides (PK). Each lipid category has its own sublassification hierarchy.

All lipids in the LIPID MAPS Structure Database (LMSD) have been classified using this system and have been assigned LIPID MAPS ID (LM_ID) which reflects their position in the classification hierarchy. The classification system was developed by the members of LIPID MAPS consortium.

LicenseNote: WIPO retains full copyright ownership of all material unless otherwise specified.

StringWithMarkup.String: The World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) International Patent Classification (IPC), established by the Strasbourg Agreement 1971, provides for a hierarchical system of language independent symbols for the classification of patents and utility models according to the different areas of technology to which they pertain.

The IPC divides technology into eight sections with approximately 70,000 subdivisions. Each subdivision has a symbol consisting of Arabic numerals and letters of the Latin alphabet. The appropriate IPC symbols are indicated on each patent document, of which more than 1,000,000 were issued each year in the last 10 years. The IPC symbols are allotted by the national or regional industrial property office that publishes the patent document.  For PCT documents, IPC symbols are allotted by the International Searching Authority (ISA). The Classification is indispensable for the retrieval of patent documents in the search for "prior art." Such retrieval is needed by patent-issuing authorities, potential inventors, research and development units, and others concerned with the application or development of technology.

LicenseNote: Academic users may freely use the KEGG website. Non-academic use of KEGG generally requires a commercial license

StringWithMarkup.String: This classification was created automatically from the PubChem Compound TOC on 2025/05/13.
Note that in some cases a number of highly populated nodes - those for which all or nearly all IDs have information - have been left out of the tree.

The sections, along with their child subsections, that are not shown in this tree are: Computed Properties, Substances by Category, Computed Descriptors, Molecular Formula, Depositor-Supplied Synonyms, Removed Synonyms, Create Date, Modify Date, Record Title, Related Compounds, Related Compounds with Annotation, Related Substances, 2D Structure, 3D Conformer, and Chemical Vendors.

StringWithMarkup.String: FDA pharmacologic class is a group of active moieties that share scientifically documented properties and is defined on the basis of any combination of attributes of the active moiety.

FDA published a final rule that amended the requirements for the content and format of approved labeling (prescribing information) for human prescription drug and biological products in January 2006. The prescribing information format is intended to make it easier for health care professionals to access, read, and use to make prescribing decisions.

LicenseNote: Use of all or parts of the material requires reference to the WHO Collaborating Centre for Drug Statistics Methodology. Copying and distribution for commercial purposes is not allowed. Changing or manipulating the material is not allowed.

StringWithMarkup.String: The WHO ATC (Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical) classification system classify the active substances into different groups according to the organ or system on which they act and their therapeutic, pharmacological and chemical properties.

Drugs are classified in groups at five different levels. The drugs are divided into fourteen main groups (1st level), with pharmacological/therapeutic subgroups (2nd level).  The 3rd and 4th levels are chemical/pharmacological/therapeutic subgroups and the 5th level is the chemical substance. The 2nd, 3rd and 4th levels are often used to identify pharmacological subgroups when that is considered more appropriate than therapeutic or chemical subgroups.  Substances classified in the same ATC 4th level cannot be considered pharmacotherapeutically equivalent since their mode of action, therapeutic effect, drug interactions and adverse drug reaction profile may differ.

Medicinal products are classified according to the main therapeutic use of the main active ingredient, on the basic principle of only one ATC code for each route of administration (i.e. pharmaceutical forms with similar ingredients and strength will have the same ATC code).  Immediate and slow release tablets will normally have the same ATC code.

A medicinal product can be given more than one ATC code if it is available in two or more strengths or routes of administration with clearly different therapeutic uses.  Normally, different stereoisomeric forms will have separate ATC codes.  Prodrugs are usually assigned separate ATC codes if the dosages used are different and/or the nonproprietary name of the prodrug and the active drugs are different.
This classification was created for the PubChem BioAssay on 2025/05/11.
Note that in some cases a number of highly populated nodes - those for which all or nearly all IDs have information - have been left out of the tree.
Safer Choice of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) helps consumers, businesses, and purchasers find products that perform and are safer for human health and the environment.
This classification is created based on the use classes of each chemical ingredient from the EPA Safer Choice.

The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures.

It sets up criteria for the classification of chemicals for physical-chemical, health, and environmental hazards of chemical substances and mixtures and sets up standardized hazard information to facilitate global trade of chemicals. Please note that obsolete codes are added in this classification for completeness purposes, as they are still in use. Any obsolete codes are annotated as such. For GHS summary, visit this website.
ChemIDplus is a TOXNET (TOXicology data NETwork) databases that contain chemicals and drugs related information.
ChemIDplus is a product of the National Library of Medicine (NLM). Last dataset: 2023/02/22

LicenseNote: CAMEO Chemicals and all other CAMEO products are available at no charge to those organizations and individuals (recipients) responsible for the safe handling of chemicals. However, some of the chemical data itself is subject to the copyright restrictions of the companies or organizations that provided the data.

StringWithMarkup.String: CAMEO Chemical Reactivity Classification was created based on the reactive groups.

Reactive groups are categories of chemicals that exhibit similar reactivity due to their structural similarities. For purposes of predicting reactivity between mixed chemicals, each substance in CAMEO Chemicals is classified into one or more reactive groups based on its known chemical properties. For further details, please visit the CAMEO Chemicals website.

StringWithMarkup.String:
The ChEMBL Protein Target Tree is a structured classification of the protein target entities contained with the ChEMBL resource release version 35
ChEMBL.

StringWithMarkup.String: ENZYME is a repository of information relative to the nomenclature of enzymes. It is primarily based on the recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee of the International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (IUBMB) and it describes each type of characterized enzyme for which an EC (Enzyme Commission) number has been provided.

LicenseNote: Gene Ontology Consortium data and data products are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/legalcode)

StringWithMarkup.String: A biological process is the execution of a genetically-encoded biological module or program. It consists of all the steps required to achieve the specific biological objective of the module. A biological process is accomplished by a particular set of molecular functions carried out by specific gene products (or macromolecular complexes), often in a highly regulated manner and in a particular temporal sequence.

LicenseNote: Gene Ontology Consortium data and data products are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/legalcode)

StringWithMarkup.String: A location, relative to cellular compartments and structures, occupied by a macromolecular machine. There are three types of cellular components described in the gene ontology: (1) the cellular anatomical entity where a gene product carries out a molecular function (e.g., plasma membrane, cytoskeleton) or membrane-enclosed compartments (e.g., mitochondrion); (2) virion components, where viral proteins act, and (3) the stable macromolecular complexes of which gene product are parts (e.g., the clathrin complex).

LicenseNote: Gene Ontology Consortium data and data products are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/legalcode)

StringWithMarkup.String: A molecular process that can be carried out by the action of a single macromolecular machine, usually via direct physical interactions with other molecular entities. Function in this sense denotes an action, or activity, that a gene product (or a complex) performs.

StringWithMarkup.String: The Taxonomy database is a curated classification and nomenclature for all of the organisms in the public sequence databases. This currently represents about 10% of the described species of life on the planet.

The CDD Classification Tree has been manually curated by Collaborative Drug Discovery, Inc. for the BioassayExpress.com project. It contains assays annotated with controlled vocabularies from sources such as Bioassassy Ontology (BAO) and other relevant biological ontologies.

CPDat (Chemical and Products Database) is a resource for exposure-relevant data on chemicals in consumer products.

The database contains information mapping more than 49,000 chemicals to a set of terms categorizing their usage or function in 16,000 consumer products. Reference: The Chemical and Products Database, a resource for exposure-relevant data on chemicals in consumer products, Scientific Data, volume 5, Article number: 180125 (2018), DOI:10.1038/sdata.2018.125.

StringWithMarkup.String: The NORMAN Suspect List Exchange (NORMAN-SLE) is a central access point for NORMAN members (and others) to find suspect lists relevant for their environmental monitoring questions.

This Exchange documents all individual collections that (will) form a part of NORMAN SusDat, the merged NORMAN Substance Database (DOI:10.5281/zenodo.2664077). Each list/collection has a DOI in Zenodo.

LicenseNote: Unless otherwise indicated, information on Department of Justice websites is in the public domain and may be copied and distributed without permission. Citation of the Department of Justice as source of the information is appreciated, as appropriate.

StringWithMarkup.String: The DEA (Drug Enforcement Administration) drug and chemical classification tree contains chemical substances from the controlled substance schedules, substance classes, and regulated chemical lists. [21 eCFR-II]

The controlled substances are classified into 5 categories [Controlled Substances Act (21 USC sec. 801 et seq.) and 21 eCFR 1308.11-1308.15], and the chemical control program contains List I and List II chemicals [21 eCFR Section 1310.02(a)(b)].

CCSbase is an integrated platform consisting of a comprehensive database of Collision Cross Section (CCS) measurements taken from a variety of sources and a high-quality and high-throughput CCS prediction model trained with this database using machine learning.

CCSbase curates experimental CCS values measured on various ion mobility platforms as a resource for the research community. CCSbase also builds prediction models for comprehensive prediction of collision cross sections for a given molecule.
This classification lists the chemical categories from the EPA CompTox Chemicals Dashboard.
More information can be found at Chemical Lists website.
This classification aggregates experimental CCS data available in PubChem, from NORMAN-SLE, CCSbase, and Baker Lab.

Additional information can be found at the NORMAN-SLE (https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/classification/#hid=101), CCSbase (https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/classification/#hid=104), and Baker Lab (https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/classification/#hid=124) classifications.

StringWithMarkup.String: The aim of a World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS) is to provide an authoritative and comprehensive list of names of marine organisms, including information on synonymy.
PFAS and Fluorinated Compounds in PubChem

The collection of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and other fluorinated compounds in PubChem as described in https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.est.3c04855. The 'OECD PFAS definition' (no salts) and 'PFAS breakdowns by chemistry' (with salts/mixtures) nodes contain PubChem content matching the OECD PFAS definition of saturated CF2 (Report ENV/CBC/MONO(2021)25). Other nodes explore 'organofluorine compounds'; 'other diverse fluorinated compounds'; 'PFAS and fluorinated compound collections' (including CompTox; NORMAN-SLE; NIST; OntoChem PFAS lists) and 'regulatory PFAS collections' (including Stockholm Convention/EU regulations for PFOS; PFOA; PFHxS; LC-PFCAs). Expand each node for more detailed content. Read more about this tree here: https://gitlab.com/uniluxembourg/lcsb/eci/pubchem-docs/-/raw/main/pfas-tree/PFAS_Tree.pdf?inline=false
Read more about this tree here: https://gitlab.com/uniluxembourg/lcsb/eci/pubchem-docs/-/raw/main/pfas-tree/PFAS_Tree.pdf

StringWithMarkup.String: Haz-MapÂ® is an occupational health database designed for health and safety professionals and consumers seeking information about the adverse effects of workplace exposures to chemical and biological agents.

The main links in Haz-Map are between chemicals and occupational diseases. These links have been established using current scientific evidence. Haz-Map classification provides the categories or classes of the chemical agents based on the activities, processes, and diseases.

The Pistoia Classification Tree has been manually curated by Pistoia Alliance Members, for the Data Fairy project, and using the BioHarmony Annotator (BioMetaData.com) technology which is provided by Collaborative Drug Discovery, Inc. (collaborativedrug.com). The tree contains assays annotated with controlled vocabularies from sources such as Bioassassy Ontology (BAO) and other relevant biological ontologies.
Authors: Pistoia Alliance and Collaborative Drug Discovery, Inc. (CDD)
Contributors: (Pistoia Alliance) Nick Lynch, Vladimir Makarov, Thomas Liener

Contributors: (Pistoia Alliance Member) Isabella Feierberg (Astrazeneca), Martin Romacker (Roche), Timothy Ikeda (Astrazeneca), Rama Balakrishnan (Genetech), Anosha Siripala (Novartis), Gabriel Backiananthan (Novartis), Dana Vanderwall (Bristol-Meyers Squibbs)
Contributors: (Collaborative Drug Discovery) Barry Bunin, Samantha Jeschonek, Whitney Smith, Jason Bret Harris
Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources.

It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute. More information can be found at https://sor.epa.gov/sor_internet/registry/substreg/LandingPage.do

SourceName: Baker Lab, Chemistry Department, The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0

StringWithMarkup.String: Catalogue of Life (COL) is a collaboration bringing together the effort and contributions of taxonomists and informaticians from around the world.

LicenseNote: This work (Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS), by www.itis.gov), is free of known copyright restrictions. Information presented on the ITIS website is considered public information and may be distributed or copied.

StringWithMarkup.String: The Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS) is an American partnership of federal agencies designed to provide consistent and reliable information on the taxonomy of biological species.

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA (40 eCFR I-R). The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

GlyTouCan provides stable accessions for glycans described at varyious degrees of characterization, including compositions (no linkage) and topologies (no carbon bond positions or anomeric configurations). GNOme organizes these stable accessions for interative browsing, for text-based searching, and for automated reasoning with well-defined characterization levels. License: CC BY 4.0

LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0

StringWithMarkup.String: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Chemicals in PubChem from Regulatory Sources
PubChem chemicals with regulatory data sources provides list of chemicals with annotation specific to regulatory data sources.

These include classifications or groupings of chemicals specific to a given agency and may help to summarize chemical substances covered by specific regulations or specific chemical substance use cases. It is important to note that this is compiled from annotation found in PubChem and might not be exhaustive or current. Always consult the respective regulatory agency for authoritative information and guidance.
